abstract.p: In this work we present a visualization system for interactive realtime animation and visualization of simulation results from a parallel Particle-In-Cell code. The system was designed and implemented for the Onyx2 InifiniteReality hardware. A number of different visual objects, such as volume rendered particle density functionals were implemented. To provide sufficient frame rates for interactive visualization the system was designed to provide performance close to the hardware specifications both in terms of the I/O and graphics subsystems. The presented case study applies the developed system to the evolution of an instability that gives rise to a plasma surfatron, a mechanism which rapidly can accelerate particles to very high velocities and thus be of great importance in the context of electron acceleration in astrophysical shocks, in the solar corona and in particle accelerators. The produced visualizations have allowed us to identify a previously unknown saturation mechanism for the surfatron and direct research efforts into new areas of interest.

div.head: Introduction and Presentation of Case
div.p: Particle-In-Cell (PIC) simulations in plasma physics approximate (continuous) electric and magnetic fields through discretization. The particles are modeled by clustering "real" charged plasma particles to computational super-particles [1]. The reduced number of particles allows us to model the plasma on a computer, but also introduces larger random fluctuations in the charge and the current density (noise). PIC simulations are demanding in terms of computer time and typically requires massively parallel computing resources. Our PIC code is a parallel implementation of the code described in [3]. The code exhibits close to linear scaling up to 128 processors on a Cray T3E.

The time scales, over which physical processes in plasma physics develop, can differ by orders of magnitude. The individual physical processes are often coupled and can not be analyzed separately. We thus have to set the sampling rate such that it can well resolve the physical time-scale of the fastest process and still save data over a simulation time that is long enough to track the slowest process until its saturation, therefore very large data sets are obtained.
In this case study we look at wave-particle interactions in a magnetized plasma acting on specific parts of the electron phase-space
, see figures 2 -4. We model one spatial dimension and let the magnetic field point in the ¥ -direction. The phase-space is reduced to the three dimensions ¡ £ ¢ ¦ ¤ § © ¢ ¦ ¤

The simultaneous need for high sampling rates in time and velocity over large time and velocity intervals poses a severe challenge to both data storage capacity and the visualization hardware. In this work we apply real-time interactive visualization in combination with animation of the time series of logged data from the simulations. The use of real-time graphics enables an active exploration of the data [16,2,5], i.e. choice of views, change of visualization parameters and even on-the-fly change of visual objects. Adding animation enables the treatment of a complete dataset consisting of subsets (time slices), each representing one snapshot of the simulation.

div.head: Interactive Streaming
div.p: In the performed PIC simulations, around two million electrons are included. During run-time of the simulations the particle data is transformed to structured data in the form of electron density volumes. Another dataset in the form of particle phase-space positions is produced from one of the computational nodes. It is these data files that provide the input to the developed Data Management System (DMS).
Given the real-time demands the DMS must support:
1. Reading and delivering data at rates of 10 -30 slices/s. Each slice represents one rendered image.
2. Animation direction and speed control, i.e. random access of slices.

div.head: Handling of data spread across different file systems
div.p: These demands have led to a design in which the data sets are split into slices and an index file is used to keep records of the slices. One or more files contain the data slices and individual slices need not be of the same size. An abstraction layer hides the use of files and it is possible to use decentralized data and access the data by network communication proxies, which enables computational steering or on-line access to simulations on super computers. The choice of the slicing dimension is arbitrary and the data can be reordered. The access into the data set is made in two steps. First the appropriate slice is retrieved from disk, and second, the correct element in the current slice is accessed. This access scheme introduces some constraints for the access to the data set but provides a suitable cue (load slice from disk) to the DMS about what data that is to be accessed next.

div.p: A custom designed Particle Data Visualizer (PDV) system is used in conjunction with the data management system to visualize the data produced in the PIC simulations. div.head: Render graphical data to image
div.p: The objects designed and implemented in PDV use a two stage pipeline. A visual object then has a separate load and generation thread which runs in parallel with the rendering thread (the main thread).

div.head: 3D -Volume Renderer
div.p: There are many proposed algorithms and solutions for volume rendering [10,8,12]. In this work volume slicing has been used [11]. Volume slicing uses textures and polygons to sample a volume and render it. This technique enables the use of hardware support for texturing. The used architecture, InfiniteReality [9], has support for three-dimensional textures, and a data volume can be directly downloaded to the graphics system as a 3D-texture. A set of polygons intersecting the volume is then sampling the texture. The polygons are oriented so their normals coincide with the viewing direction. There are two cases; orthographic projection and perspective projection. In this work parallel polygons have been implemented and used. As long as the distance to the volume is not too small, this method is sufficient. Support for 3D-textures gives some benefits compared to twodimensional textures. The volume does not need to be sliced up and reorganized depending on the view angle. The border artifacts are reduced, which are very noticeable when the slicing polygon normals must deviate largely from the view angle. Hardware support for three-dimensional textures also allow for fast trilinear interpolation between voxels.

The image is rendered by drawing polygons, intersecting the volume, in a back to front order and compose them with blending. The polygons are given a color and the voxel values replace the alphacomponent.

The main bottleneck in this technique and for this particular case is the fill-rate of the graphics system. A recent addition to the system has been made to use two 3D-textures such that one can be used for rendering while the other is updated. This is discussed more in section 4.2.

div.head: 3D -Particle Rendering
div.p: The second visual object shows individual electrons as points. It is not possible to animate and view the whole set of electrons from the simulations in real-time. Therefore we use a suitable subset of the electrons of one tenth of the total number of particles. This has resulted in 212 000 electrons. A view of the Particles visual object is shown in figure 7.

To provide a depth cue, the fog support in OpenGL is used to fade electrons that are farther away and can be blending applied. To reduce the size of the data, the phase-space coordinates are stored in 16 bit fixed point. A double buffer scheme is used to pipeline the particle data. The back buffer is used by the loader thread that loads the data from disk. The front buffer is used by the rendering thread to render the points.

div.head: Performance Measurements and Physical Results
div.p: The system used in this case study was an SGI Onyx2 Reality-Monser with 12 CPUs and three InfiniteReality pipes, each with four RM7 boards. Data was stored using three SCSI-controllers to manage an Extended Logical Volume (XLV) with six striped disks. The result from diskperf shows that we are close to the maximum performance for forward sequential read. In random read mode, we match the results of random read.

div.head: Physical Results
div.p: Our PIC simulation has modeled a surfatron in a self-consistent way. A surfatron is formed out of an electrostatic wave with an electric field vector
propagating across a magnetic field 9 ¥

. We have considered the case when the energy source is a proton beam. The plasma in which astrophysical shocks are immersed is typically magnetized and contains dense beams of charged particles [4]. Our case study is thus relevant to electron acceleration (injection) in astrophysical shocks. The electron acceleration could then explain the origin of highly energetic cosmic rays [4].

The PDV has enabled the verification of the analytical prediction in [6] that the surfatron can rapidly and efficiently accelerate electrons, as seen in figures 5 -7. The PDV tool has allowed us to examine the building up and the consecutive saturation of the surfatron in form of an animation. We can simultaneously visualize all relevant space and velocity components of the plasma. Previously we have only been able to show either a two dimensional (reduced) dataset in form of an animation or three dimensional snapshots of the phase space evolution. The nature of the surfatron implies, however, a complicated three dimensional temporal coupling. Our animation has shown that the electrons gyrate around a cone in ¡ £ ¢ ¤ § ¢ ¤ space which has its axis oriented in ¤ -direction, see figure 5. The cone expands along its axis and moves along the ¡ direction with a changing velocity. While the acceleration in the y-direction has been predicted in [6], the detailed phase space evolution was unknown.

div.head: Future Work
div.p: As a part of the animation control recording of scene manipulation will be included so it can be used for high quality off-line rendering.
A visual object combining volume and particle data in the same renderer will be implemented. Furthermore the PDV system will be prepared for integration with various immersive VR environments.

We anticipate that the PDV tool will also enable the further understanding of the interplay between the individual saturation mechanisms of the surfatron. This will allow us to determine for which plasma parameters the surfatron can provide an injection mechanism. This, in turn, may help to predict what type of astrophysical shocks can generate the highly energetic cosmic rays we observe on Earth [4].
